text: hello everyone today we'll talk about
the role of cloud-based simulation in
development and testing of robot
applications AWS Robo maker brings cloud
scale to simulations the technical
benefits include the ability to run
hundreds of concurrent simulations with
the Robo maker batch API fully managed
AWS infrastructure which enables you to
run your simulations consistently and
reliably with by the minute
pay-as-you-go pricing you only pay for
simulations when you're using them you
get the benefits of a managed service
with Ross and gazebo built in which will
free up engineering resources finally
the ease of integration with the breadth
of AWS services enables you to connect
your Ross application and tooling with
services like Amazon Cloud watch logs
and AWS code pipeline one of the key
software validation best practices is
regression testing with a continuous
integration and continuous delivery or C
ICD pipeline AWS Robo maker makes it
easy to test your robot applications
under many scenarios by running tens or
hundreds of in parallel parameterize
simulations with a single API call these
tests can be triggered with every code
commit in your CI pipeline or with
nightly builds to reduce the number of
software defects and ensure that your
new code does not have unintended
consequences on robot behavior with over
five million units actively deployed
iRobot uses AWS Robo maker in their
continuous integration pipeline to
easily scale and run hundreds of tests
and simulation for each software release
candidate
let's see how this works in AWS first
we'll open up the a device Robo maker
console for this quick demo I'll use the
development environment in the cloud the
robot application we're using today is a
robot monitoring sample application
which you can find in the ativ s
robotics github organization so let's
say our customers expect our robot to be
able to navigate autonomously in
multiple different room layouts and
locations you'll notice in this JSON
document we have defined a set of
environment variables for each scenario
testing for the behavior that our
customers are expecting once these
scenarios are defined we can go ahead
and merge our code changes into an
integration branch a webhook has been
configured in github with AWS code
pipeline a managed continuous delivery
service to start a new job the Ross
application will be built and bundled
using coal con in AWS code build a
managed build service once complete a
batch of ADA base Robo makers simulation
jobs are triggered and monitored through
a set of compute functions running in
AWS lambda each simulation job runs a
single scenario and when complete
automatically self terminates with the
test results tagged to the simulation
job let's open one of the simulation
jobs you can see that the robot is
navigating to multiple goals once
complete the job will tag the test
results in self-terminate finally the
results for all of the tests are
analyzed and the code integration is
either passed or failed to learn more
about how your business could use AWS
troublemaker check out our website at
AWS Amazon comm slash Robo maker there
you'll find links to our technical blogs
that describe many use cases like
automated testing and fleet simulation
finally get hands-on a troublemaker
workshops calm thanks for watching
